review_headline: A solid VICTORY for an over-crowded apartment!
review_body:
I've been looking for ways to increase storage space. I live in a 2 bed 1 bath apartment with my girlfriend, and our two Siberian Huskies, and another couple. Needless to say, we are all packed in there like sardines! Now, let's be honest here... 50% of the space is for the other couple, 60% of the space is for the pups, and the other 30% is my girlfriends. The numbers don't lie... we definitely have no more space at this point! I bought this for me, in hopes that I can re-claim a percentage of space for myself. Bed risers just weren't going to do the trick, and wooden framed with built-in drawers are much out of my price range. For me, this was a solid meet-me-in-the-middle solution.

FIRST IMPRESSIONS:
The actual storage space of each of the two "cavities" from floor to the under-bars measures at about 12-1/2"tall x 30"wide x 60"deep. I've very pleased to say that I was able to fit EIGHT (count em'), EIGHT large 12" storage tubs under the bed! The tubs were about 8 bucks each at our local "w-mart". We have gotten rid of the box spring completely, without any issues so far, and we feel no difference in comfort without it. Our mattress is an old 8" coil spring with a separate 3" memory foam mattress topper on the mattress. I could see how some may say a solid 8" memory foam mattress might sag through the spaces. Some have put down cardboard for that, but I didn't find it necessary with our mattress. So far, we've been sleeping on this bed for a few weeks and it seems very solid, give or take a husky and some horseplay. It's very quiet, and I have not hears and creeks or squeaks from the frame as of yet.

My worries were put aside when we finally received it in the mail. I was reading others reviews and was initially concerned about the frame arriving damaged during shipping as others have stated. Although, the box did arrive with a few minor bumps and bruises, there was zero damage and no rust to actual frame. I LOVE that this frame folds up, that's a really nice convenience. It took me all of 20 minutes to un-box and setup this frame where the old one used to be. There was very little assembly that I actually had to do. I was surprised that I did not need any tools what-so-ever. The only thing that confused me for a moment was the brackets that lock the outer legs in place. Those needed to be rotated PRIOR to fully folding out the legs, and then they lined up just fine. The cross-bars are not flush with the other length-wise support bars, and that is a bit of a pet peeve for me, but not that big of a deal. I'm definitely satisfied, and I would recommend this product.ctual frame. I LOVE that this frame folds up, that's a really nice convenience. review_headline: I swear by Sauder -- this is my 30th piece (no kidding)
review_body:

It is par for the course to have a few pieces arrive damaged in shipping, and yes Sauder, obviously damaged in the factory BEFORE packaging. But Sauder makes it right (usually, see below). Just hop on their website and order the replacement pieces you need, free of charge. Set aside the project for a week. My parts' orders arrive within a week.

This particular desk is intricately designed and looks fabulous. It took more time than usual. It is a solid, well-designed desk which has a lot of pieces. It astounds me to see people criticize Sauder for furniture that does not come out well -- it is THEMSELVES who are the poor assemblers! I have assembled three or four other companies' furniture, and all fared poorly, and we were careful and conscientious.

The Carson Forge collection is a family's dream furniture. When I get a knick in it, I take a black magic marker to it, then fast smudge the black using Kleenex. That is all you do to make an imperfection disappear, presto chango. Plus, before assembly, take Carson Forge pieces and with a magic marker, blacken all the edges, smudging with Kleenex.

Sauder is now middle-class furniture. It is what people can afford. Sauder, for the most part, cares about its customers. Only one time did I have a bad experience -- for an armoire, more than six pieces came damaged. Sauder balks when the number of pieces to send out free is over their quota. I told her no (and in no uncertain terms, that she could shove it). My husband intervened, complied, and emailed pictures. It was humiliating and degrading -- overall a bad experience. But that was unusual. I hope to not have a repeat of that. If it happens again, I will be contacting their Chairman of the Board and President, and scream bloody murder. It may be that people abuse their free replacement service, but why the heck does Sauder not take note when I contact them that I had (at the time) over 25 pieces of their furniture in my home, and I am not a crank. Take a trip to any furniture store. Bring a flashlight. Go up to a wall unit, open a cabinet, tap on side walls, bottoms of drawers, very top of the unit. Much of the woods there are 1/4\\" thick. product_title: 8" Night Therapy Spring Mattress & Bi-Fold® Box Spring Set
review_body:
A full size mattress is approximately 72-inches long by 54-inches wide, and this set was advertised as being 8-inches thick. When this set arrived, in two boxes, I went back to the listing thinking that I had misunderstood the listing.

The box for the spring was only 54-inches by 47-inches by 5-inches. I felt that there was no way an 8-inch spring could fit in it. I was certainly surprised when we unfolded the spring and it expanded itself to a full size and 8-inch thickness. I did not look closely to see how this transformation was accomplished, but just looked at it in wonder.

Similarly, the mattress box measured 18-inches by 18-inches by 39-inches. Again, certainly not large enough for a full size mattress of 8-inches thickness. Once again I was totally surprised. The mattress was rolled into a tight roll. When we removed it from the box and unrolled it on the bed, it self-expanded to its full size.

I have been sleeping on it for about two weeks now, and this is my impression. As advertised, it is a firm mattress set, but with enough "give" to make it very comfortable. The 8-inch thickness of the springs and the mattress mean that the top is 18-inches from the bed frame. For some shorter people, it may make getting into bed a bit more challenging. As arthritis is destroying my joints and spine, this may become a problem for me.

Over all, I recommend this set.

review_body:
I live in a small apartment, and like many small apartments, this one doesn't have a separate dining area. I have a tiny corner of the living room with which to place a dining table – so I really needed one that was nice and compact. However, I also wanted one that was big enough to serve as extra table space for when I'm working on prepping a larger meal (because, yes, the kitchen is tiny, too). This was a bit of dilemma before I struck on the idea of getting a table with drop leaves. Unfortunately, it seems that smaller tables with drop leaves are somewhat hard to find, but after much searching, I came across this table, the "Winsome Wood Hamilton Double Drop Leaf Dining Table."

The first thing I love about it is its smaller footprint – it measures just 30" by 26" across with the leaves down, and 30" by 42" across with the leaves fully extended (do keep in mind, though, if you happen to be trying to jam this into some tiny niche, that when the leaves are down they still take up some space while hanging, so the table is more like 30" by 28" wide). Also, I like the tiny drawer. It's not really big enough to hold much, but I appreciate the effort at putting in a bit of storage. Plus, it kinda makes the desk look almost like a writing desk, so I could see this table serving multiple functions, making it a nice multi-purpose piece. Speaking of versatility, I also like how the table keeps to a simple, classic style without being too boring (the tapered legs give it some visual interest), to where it could look equally well with a contemporary decorating scheme or a more traditional one.

In terms of quality, I should mention that the leaves are sturdy and stable (very much so) when extended. What's also awesome is the fact that the table is made out of actual solid wood (with the exception of the interior of the drawer, which I'm pretty sure is made of some sort of composite. Color-wise, it's pretty spot-on to the online picture, and I'd describe it as a walnut color (just like the listing does). The finish is also pretty good, at least on the top and legs. The underside of the table isn't very well-sanded (feels rough), and I can tell that they put a thinner coat of varnish on it. So, that's clearly where they cheaped out. Still, for a table that's made of real wood for this price point, I'm not going to complain.

Overall I'd have to say this table is a fantastic value for what you're getting. It's solid wood, has a reasonably decent finish, is sturdy, and is attractive, all for the price of $120 (as of the time of writing this review). You really can't beat that, and if you are desperately searching for a tiny dining table for a small space that still looks nice, then this really is a great choice.

product_title: SmartMotion Executive SwingChair (black)
review_headline: The only chair I can use for long periods at a desk due to spinal problems
review_body:
I've used this chair for 8 years now. Mine is starting to wear out (nothing that is irreplaceable, the material on the arm rests wore down, and I'd like a taller gas lift, etc).

I've been looking around for parts for the chair for awhile and am not having much luck. It appears the older model (the one pictured) was discontinued awhile back. Luckily the 2 things that need work are not too hard to do without the official parts. I will just re-upholster the arms and I believe I can find a compatible generic gas lift.

So why bother to review? Because this chair is solid (I weigh 250-275, varied throughout the years) and will last you a long time. And NO ONE else seems to offer this swinging seat base. Understandable as it requires a lot of metal to make it that strong and design companies don't want to deal with a lot of heavy shipping (and it isn't the prettiest thing in the world). However this seat literally makes the difference for me to be able to sit at my computer or not after many spinal surgeries and some really ugly spinal complications.

For my specifics, I've got 4 fused levels in my lumbar spine, 2 in my cervical spine, as well as a condition called Adhesive Arachnoiditis (complication from a surgery).

If you have a bad back, you'll be amazed what allowing your legs to adjust regularly does for your ability to stay comfortable. Do you ever ride in a car with power seats and find yourself adjusting the tilt of the seat throughout the drive due to back aches? That is what you get to do here, but easily and as many times as you'd like.

And the chair back is shaped well and has LOTS of height and depth (distance from the chair center) adjustability.

They still make the newer version (which I found less comfortable), but even that is becoming harder to find. If you are on the fence, get it. Don't wait too long.
